abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            satisfactory. The improvement in the power system's
            stability and safety, the turn in Bulgaria's dependence
            on foreign supplies and reserve capacity, the positive
            trends in the sector's finances, and the
            government's continuing commitment to develop the
            sector indicate that the benefits of the project are
            sustainable. Both the World Bank's and the
            Borrower's performances were overall satisfactory.
            Lessons learned include the following: Adhere to long-term
            development goals. In the case of Bulgaria, the economic
            crisis and hyperinflation fueled the government with
            numerous reasons for which they did not want to meet the
            tariff covenant. The Bank's project team held strong to
            the commitment to encouraging the government to meet the
            financial covenants of the loan and showed the government
            that it could be met and that benefits could be derived. A
            second lesson is to assess implementation capacity. The
            national electric company's (NEK) lack of capacity to
            deal with external financiers such as the Bank could have
            been addressed through specific technical assistance.
            Addressing implementation capacity up front may have also
            mitigated the problem of high staff turnover. A detailed
            assessment of implementation capacity, including
            procurement, would have helped to avoid delays. Third,
            remain flexible to adapt to emerging trends/opportunities.
            The Bank's flexibility in allowing changes in the
            project's scope expanded the project's benefits.
